text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Monday.

- Defence Minister Gojko Susak who has recently been on a working visit to Washington obtained guarantees that the U.S. would support reintegration of Eastern Slavonia into Croatia by June 1997 at the latest.
- From 1997, citizens should be able to get favourable thirty-year housing loans at a one percent annual interest, says Djuro Njavro, president's advisor for economy.
- Entrepreneur Luka Rajic, owner of the Dukat dairy, is poised to become a majority shareholder in another diary, Sirela, where he currenlty holds 42 percent.
- Mayor of Mostar, Croat Ivica Prskalo, has accused European Union special envoy in the town Sir Martin Garrod of bias against Croats.
- Experts estimate prices of newly built flats might increase by 11 to 18 percent in January due to value added tax.
- "I'll bring back Blaskic to Zagreb," says Anto Nobilo, newly appointed defence counsel of Bosnian Croat General Tihomir Blaskic, due to appear before U.N. war crimes tribunal in January.
- Local Serb and Croatian politicians are stalling the peaceful reintegration of Eastern Slavonia, says U.N. transitional administrator for the region Jacques Klein in an interview.
- Our main aim is to enter Croatian parliament, says Croatian branch of Bosnia's ruling Moslem Party of Democratic Action (SDA) at a convention held in Zagreb.

- "We'll create a strong army," says Joseph L. Allred, spokesman of Militry Professional Resources Inc., a firm in charge of the American 'Equip and Train' programme for Bosnia's Moslem-Croat federation.
- Heavy-weight boxer Zeljko Mavrovic defends the title of European champion, after he knocked out a Britih challenger in the second round. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
